## Publication Timeline and Initial Reception

The Peasants was written by Władysław Reymont in four parts between 1904 and 1909, with Autumn published in 1904, Winter in 1904, Spring in 1906, and Summer in 1909.(no content)The first parts of the story were published in the weekly magazine Tygodnik Illustrowany.(no content)Reymont published the first part of Chłopi in 1904, marking the resumption of his writing career after being severely injured in a railway accident in 1900. This publication came after his first successful and widely praised novel "The Promised Land" from 1899, which brought attention to social inequalities and labor exploitation in industrial Łódź.

## Critical Recognition and European Impact

While the search results don't provide extensive details about the immediate critical reception in 1904-1909, there are some important indicators of the work's significance:

Władysław Reymont received the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature for this work.(no content)In 1924 for the "Chłopi" he won the Nobel Prize over great writers like Hardy, Mann, Ibanez, Gorki, Undset, Grazia Deledda and Jirasek.(no content)Public opinion in Poland supported recognition for Stefan Żeromski, but the prize went to the author of Chłopi. This suggests that by the time of the Nobel Prize, there was already significant recognition of the work's literary merit, though it may not have been the most popular choice initially.

## Literary Significance

In Chłopi, Reymont created a more complete and suggestive picture of country life than any other Polish writer. The novel impresses the reader with its authenticity of the material reality, customs, behaviour and spiritual culture of the people.(no content)The novel has been translated into at least 27 languages, indicating its eventual widespread international recognition beyond its initial Polish and European reception.
